moves.1. c4 c5 2. Nc3 Nc6: i don't usually see the symmetrical with the english
moves.5. Nf3 a6 6. O-O: i like the way it started: i am well protected, and i can concentrate on attack.
moves.6... Qc7: I am not sure this is very comfortable because the queen is expose to a Knight attack. But, till now, it is not very important, though i started to think about potential traps on d5
moves.7. d3 e6 8. e4 h6 9. d4: my goal was to push on this potential trap.
moves.9... g5: that is interesting, because black does not hesitate to attack, though the king is clearly not protected and two pieces are still waiting to get out.
moves.10... Ne5 11. Nxe5 dxe5: the black position seems inadequate, though it is hard to find a real and concrete weakness. i have considered on sacrificing on g5 sometime, but 1) i was lacking of material; 2) it could have opened my own king side; 3) I had a better plan on queen side
moves.12. Be3 Bd6 13. a3 O-O-O: this is very dangerous, now, because all my pieces converges there. now my plan on queen side has much more sense
moves.14. Qe2 f5: who will be first? My d5 is still in my mind: in two moves from now
moves.15. dxe6: too late for the black attack
moves.15... Bxe6 16. exf5 Bxf5: so now my d5-knight is open. Bf7 was not better, though, for the loss of a pawn, at least it kept some activity
moves.17. Nd5 Qg7: and everything seems open for my bishops and my precious knight. Was there a better place for the queen?
moves.18... cxb4 19. axb4: 2 valorous pawns, a knight, two bishops and my queen are on the verge to attack an exposed king...
moves.19... Ne7: necessary. But in the mean time blocking the queen from king side
moves.20. Nb6+: i want to keep him, so i launch him on the brink.
moves.20... Kb8: Kc7 was a mess because of c5, losing a bishop.
moves.21. c5: this is just too good to be true: the black queen is out and the bishops diagonals are opening everywhere
moves.22... Bxb6: if bxa, then it is checkmate in very few moves. so, this was the only possible move. My knight has been brave and fell for the good of every one
moves.23. Rxb6: i wonder, maybe i had to sacrifice the rook and take with the pawn... Not sure.
moves.23... e4: blocking my diagonal, good move, i think, but will not stop me from my attack
moves.24... Nc8: threatening the draw by three-fold repetition. Actually, i previewed this move, but didn't know exactly if my attack was still possible. Though i refused to stop it
moves.25. Rb5 Na7 26. Rb6 Nc8: hm, i had to chose where to lose the rook
moves.27. Ra1 Nxb6: and i can't take it back with the queen, or i lose the other rook
moves.28... Kc8: of course not Kc7, because it would give me a tempo when i take the knight... But mostly, it gives me... the queen: if Kc7, then Qxb6+ and whatever the king does the queen will fall after two or three moves.
moves.29. cxb6: prohibiting Kd7, giving me another tempo... and the queen
moves.30. Rc1+: yep, that move is the best one and at least regain the loss. But at least it saved the queen.
moves.32. Qc6+: allowing passage to my pawns... and now i have to make them protect each other.
moves.33... Qxc7: i wonder if Qe7 was maybe better
moves.34. bxc7: because i don't see how to stop them now
moves.35. b5 Rd5 36. b6 Rb5: this is too kind: my light bishop can now take place in game
moves.38... Ra8 39. b7: only move: Rxb7... So black resigned
